title: Ferrol Naval Base
text:
Ferrol Naval Base also known as the Arsenal of Ferrol is a <a href="military%20base">military base</a> and <a href="arsenal">arsenal</a> of the <a href="Spanish%20Navy">Spanish Navy</a> located in <a href="Ferrol%2C%20Galicia">Ferrol</a>, <a href="Spain">Spain</a>. It is the main Spanish naval base on the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic</a>.
History.
The first warships arrived in the <a href="R%C3%ADas%20Altas">Ría de Ferrol</a> in the 16th century, during the reign of the <a href="House%20of%20Austria">House of Austria</a>. It was not until 1724 when <a href="Felipe%20V%20of%20Spain">Felipe V</a>, of the <a href="House%20of%20Bourbon">House of Bourbon</a>, established Ferrol as the main port of the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic</a>.
Major development and expansion of the shipyards and arsenal began in the 1740s and 1750s. Initial proposals were drawn up under Minister of the Navy <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Pati%C3%B1o">José Patiño</a>, and executed by his successor, <a href="Zen%C3%B3n%20de%20Somodevilla%20y%20Bengoechea">Zenón de Somodevilla y Bengoechea</a>, Marquis de la Ensenadahe, appointed Minister of the Navy in 1743. The first ship, the "San Fernando", was launched in 1751. By then twelve ships could be being built simultaneously. <a href="Charles%20III%20of%20Spain">King Charles III</a> was particularly interested in the navy, and in 1790, during his reign, the arsenal at Ferrol was largely completed, with a workforce of 5,440 men and a capacity to maintain 70 ships.
Technological developments during the <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> led to the establishment of the School of Machinists and the School of Naval Engineers in 1850, during the reign of <a href="Isabella%20II%20of%20Spain">Isabel II</a>. A <a href="steam%20engine">steam engine</a> workshop was also established. At the beginning of the 20th century, the first Spanish <a href="battleship">battleship</a>s, the <a href="Espa%C3%B1a-class%20battleship">"España" class</a>, were built in Ferrol. By 1912 the shipyards of Ferrol were primarily building battleships and <a href="cruiser">cruiser</a>s, while <a href="destroyer">destroyer</a>s and <a href="submarine">submarine</a>s were built in <a href="Cartagena%20Naval%20Base">Cartagena</a>.
The Ferrol naval base was substantially modernized during the twentieth century. The <a href="Spanish%20Navy%20Marines">Navy Marine Corps</a> Barracks were built; as were the Electricity and Electronics Workshop and new warehouses. New facilities for docks 1 and 2 were constructed, as was a <a href="Cannon">Cannon</a> Workshop. The docks have been expanded, and vessels can be moored around the basin. In 2003 dock 5 was enlarged to fit the <a href="%C3%81lvaro%20de%20Baz%C3%A1n-class%20frigate">"Álvaro de Bazán"-class</a> <a href="frigates">frigates</a>. In 2013 the Naval Archive of Ferrol was inaugurated.
